Introduction

The thyroid gland can be involved with both primary and metastatic malignancy.  Major categories of primary thyroid cancer include:

  • Papillary thyroid cancer
  • Follicular thyroid cancer
  • Oncocytic carcinoma of the thyroid (HÃ¼rthle cell cancer)
  • Anaplastic thyroid cancer
  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Primary thyroid lymphoma

Clinical presentation

Thyroid malignancy most commonly presents as a nodule or mass in the lower neck.  Incidental discovery during imaging of the neck for other reasons is common, especially with less aggressive tumors.  Compression of surrounding structures may produce hoarseness, dysphagia, or neurologic compromise.  Obstruction of the vena cava may lead to Pemberton sign (ie, facial plethora induced by bilateral arm elevation).  Definitive diagnosis is usually made with fine needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.  Subsequent staging is typically accomplished with CT scan (or MRI) of the neck.

Papillary thyroid cancer

  • Presentation:  Slowly enlarging thyroid mass, most common between age 30-50.
  • Risk factors:  Most common primary thyroid cancer type; occurrence ratio female:male is 3:1; associated with BRAF gene mutations; childhood radiation exposure (eg, radiotherapy, radioactive fallout).
  • Histology:  Formation of papillae with a fibrovascular core; moderately well-differentiated cells with large clear nuclei (ie, "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei) (
    image 1
    ); psammoma bodies, which represent calcified papillae remnants (
    image 2
    ).

Follicular thyroid cancer

  • Presentation:  Enlarging thyroid mass, most common between age 40-60.
  • Risk factors:  Childhood radiation exposure.
  • Histology:  Numerous follicles resembling benign thyroid follicular adenomas but with variable cell differentiation and invasion of the thyroid capsule (
    image 3
    ).

Oncocytic carcinoma of the thyroid

  • Presentation:  Similar to follicular thyroid cancer but with aggressive course and increased risk for metastasis.
  • Histology:  Resemblance to follicular thyroid cancer with prominent HÃ¼rthle cells (round nucleus and abundant, eosinophilic cytoplasm) (
    image 4
    ).

Anaplastic thyroid cancer

  • Presentation:  Rapidly growing mass with invasion of local structures; early metastasis.
  • Risk factors:  Age >60, preexisting differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular).
  • Histology:  Disorganized, pleiomorphic cells (
    image 5
    ).

Medullary thyroid cancer

  • Presentation:  Malignancy arising from thyroid parafollicular (C) cells.
  • Risk factors:  Approximately 20% occur in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A and 2B due to germline mutations in the RET proto-oncogene (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: Multiple endocrine neoplasia MEN type 2
    ).
  • Histology:  Nests of spindle-shaped cells with positive staining for calcitonin (
    image 6
    ).

Primary thyroid lymphoma

  • Presentation:  Rapidly growing neck mass in a patient with preexisting hypothyroidism.
  • Risk factors:  Rare tumor type, but risk is increased dramatically in patients with chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis.

Differential diagnosis

The primary consideration in the differential diagnosis of thyroid malignancy is for benign thyroid adenomas.  Metabolically active nodules, which are rarely malignant, can be distinguished by a suppressed TSH and increased uptake on radioiodine scintigraphy.  Patients with metabolically active thyroid nodules need appropriate treatment for hyperthyroidism but do not need histologic confirmation.  However, nonmetabolically active nodules that do not have clearly benign features on ultrasound may require  fine needle aspiration (FNA) to exclude malignancy.

Thyroid metastasis from nonthyroidal cancer is uncommon but can occur due to the abundant vascularity of the gland.  The most common primary tumors include lung, kidney, breast, and gastrointestinal tract malignancies.

In addition, Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis (Riedel struma) is a rare disorder characterized by progressive fibrosis of the thyroid and surrounding structures.  The thyroid gland is hard, fixed, and tender but typically does not contain a dominant mass.

Treatment and follow-up

Surgery

Surgical resection is indicated for most differentiated thyroid tumors.  Unilateral lobectomy is typically performed for smaller (<4 cm) tumors with low risk of recurrence, whereas total thyroidectomy is indicated for larger (â‰¥4 cm) tumors and those with increased risk of recurrence (eg, extrathyroidal extension, lymph node metastasis, history of childhood radiation exposure).

Radioiodine therapy

Adjuvant radioiodine therapy can be used for ablation of known or occult, unresected tumor foci.  It is indicated for patients with increased risk for recurrence.  Factors favoring radioiodine therapy include large tumor size (â‰¥4 cm), extensive vascular invasion, aggressive histology (eg, oncocytic carcinoma), and regional or distal metastasis.

Levothyroxine suppression

In addition to stimulating hyperplasia and metabolic activity of normal thyroid follicles, TSH can accelerate growth of residual cancer cells in patients with differentiated thyroid cancer.  Levothyroxine therapy is prescribed for most patients following surgery and radioiodine therapy to replace thyroid hormone metabolic needs and to suppress pituitary TSH release.  TSH is maintained below typical laboratory reference ranges, with target levels determined by baseline risk of tumor recurrence.

Tumor markers

Thyroglobulin

Thyroglobulin (Tg) is a large glycoprotein that serves as a source for production of thyroid hormone (

figure 1
).  It is normally stored in thyroid follicles, and a small amount is released into circulation with thyroid hormone.  However, it is also produced by differentiated (ie, papillary, follicular) thyroid cancer and can be used as a tumor marker (
figure 2
).  Patients who have undergone a total thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine treatment should have no residual normal thyroid tissue; therefore, a rising Tg level suggests recurrent cancer.  The sensitivity can be increased by measuring a stimulated Tg level; levothyroxine therapy is briefly discontinued (or recombinant TSH administered) to allow a rise in TSH, which induces increased Tg release from any residual thyroid cancer cells that may be present.

Calcitonin

Calcitonin is secreted by parafollicular cells in response to hypercalcemia and has a minor role in calcium homeostasis.  Calcitonin levels are increased in most patients with medullary thyroid cancer, which can be useful in diagnosis and in assessing risk for recurrence.

Summary

Most primary thyroid cancer is differentiated thyroid cancer, which includes papillary and follicular thyroid cancer types.  Less common types include oncocytic carcinoma of the thyroid, anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and primary thyroid lymphoma.  Thyroid malignancy most commonly presents as a nodule or mass in the lower neck, often noted incidentally on neck imaging done for other reasons.  Compression of surrounding structures may produce hoarseness, dysphagia, or neurologic compromise.

Initial evaluation of a suspicious thyroid mass should include thyroid ultrasonography and serum TSH, which can identify the risk for malignancy.  Definitive diagnosis is usually made with fine needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.
